content.title: TypeScript Configuration Error: Missing rootDir in tsconfig files
content.body:
## Problem
Both `tsconfig.app.json` and `tsconfig.spec.json` have TypeScript compilation warnings due to missing explicit `rootDir` settings in their compiler options.

## Details

### tsconfig.app.json (Line 6)
```
"outDir": "./out-tsc/app",
```
**Error:** The common source directory of 'tsconfig.app.json' is './src'. The 'rootDir' setting must be explicitly set to this or another path to adjust your output's file layout.

### tsconfig.spec.json (Line 6)
```
"outDir": "./out-tsc/spec",
```
**Error:** The common source directory of 'tsconfig.spec.json' is './src/app'. The 'rootDir' setting must be explicitly set to this or another path to adjust your output's file layout.

## Suggested Fix
Add explicit `rootDir` compiler options to both configuration files:

**For tsconfig.app.json:**
```json
"compilerOptions": {
  "outDir": "./out-tsc/app",
  "rootDir": "./src",
  "types": []
}
```

**For tsconfig.spec.json:**
```json
"compilerOptions": {
  "outDir": "./out-tsc/spec",
  "rootDir": "./src",
  "types": [
    "vitest/globals"
  ]
}
```

## References
- [TypeScript Migration Guide](https://aka.ms/ts6)

content.title: Create organized folder structure
content.body:
Create the folder structure for the app following best practice. i.e.
```
src/
 ├── app/
 │    ├── app.config.ts
 │    ├── app.routes.ts
 │    │
 │    ├── core/
 │    │     ├── config/
 │    │     ├── guards/
 │    │     ├── interceptors/
 │    │     ├── services/
 │    │     └── core.providers.ts
 │    │
 │    ├── shared/
 │    │     ├── ui/
 │    │     │     ├── button/
 │    │     │     ├── modal/
 │    │     │     └── form-controls/
 │    │     ├── directives/
 │    │     ├── pipes/
 │    │     └── utils/
 │    │
 │    ├── layout/
 │    │     ├── header/
 │    │     ├── sidebar/
 │    │     └── layout.component.ts
 │    │
 │    ├── features/
 │    │     ├── auth/
 │    │     │     ├── login/
 │    │     │     ├── register/
 │    │     │     ├── services/
 │    │     │     └── auth.routes.ts
 │    │     │
 │    │     ├── dashboard/
 │    │     │     ├── pages/
 │    │     │     ├── components/
 │    │     │     ├── services/
 │    │     │     ├── models/
 │    │     │     └── dashboard.routes.ts
 │    │     │
 │    │     └── <more-features>/
 │    │
 │    └── state/        (optional: signals, stores, NgRx)
 │
 ├── assets/
 │    ├── images/
 │    ├── icons/
 │    ├── data/
 │    └── styles/
 │         ├── base/
 │         ├── mixins/
 │         ├── variables/
 │         └── global.scss
 │
 ├── environments/
 │    ├── environment.ts
 │    └── environment.prod.ts
 │
 └── main.ts
```

content.title: Component: Languages
content.body:
Create the component showing the spoken/written languages based on the European Union levels (https://www.coe.int/en/web/common-european-framework-reference-languages/level-descriptions)
A1 Beginner - Basic understanding in simple everyday situations
A2 Elementary - Can communicate in routine tasks requiring simple information
B1 Intermediate - Can handle most situations while traveling or in work
B2 Upper Intermediate - Can express opinions and arguments
C1 Advanced - Can use language flexibly and effectively for social, academic, and professional purposes
C2 Proficient - Near-native fluency and understanding

content.title: USERS: Create Model
content.body:
```prisma
model User {
    id         String   @id @unique @default(cuid())
    email      String   @unique
    givenName  String
    familyName String
    avatarUrl  String?
    createdAt  DateTime @default(now())
    updatedAt  DateTime @updatedAt
}
```

content.title: TASKS: Create model
content.body:
| Field          | Type          | Description                                    |
| -------------- | ------------- | ---------------------------------------------- |
| id             | String (cuid) | Unique identifier                              |
| title          | String        | Task title                                     |
| description    | String?       | Detailed task description                      |
| parentId       | String?       | Parent task for subtasks (null = root)         |
| creatorId      | String        | User who created the task                      |
| startDate      | DateTime?     | Optional task start date                       |
| dueDate        | DateTime?     | Optional due date                              |
| estimatedHours | Float?        | Estimated effort in hours                      |
| createdAt      | DateTime      | Creation timestamp                             |
| updatedAt      | DateTime      | Last update timestamp                          |

content.title: Document the models USER and TASK
content.body:
Add models explaination for USER and TASK. Include fields, data types, and relationships between the models. This will help in understanding how to structure the database and how the models interact with each other in the application.

# USER Model

| Field      | Type          | Description                |
| ---------- | ------------- | -------------------------- |
| id         | String (cuid) | Unique identifier          |
| email      | String        | User's email (unique)      |
| givenName  | String        | First name                 |
| familyName | String        | Last name                  |
| avatarUrl  | String?       | Optional avatar image URL  |
| createdAt  | DateTime      | Account creation timestamp |
| updatedAt  | DateTime      | Last update timestamp      |

# TASK Model

| Field          | Type          | Description                                    |
| -------------- | ------------- | ---------------------------------------------- |
| id             | String (cuid) | Unique identifier                              |
| title          | String        | Task title                                     |
| description    | String?       | Detailed task description                      |
| parentId       | String?       | Parent task for subtasks (null = root)         |
| creatorId      | String        | User who created the task                      |
| startDate      | DateTime?     | Optional task start date                       |
| dueDate        | DateTime?     | Optional due date                              |
| estimatedHours | Float?        | Estimated effort in hours                      |
| isRecurring    | Boolean       | Whether task repeats                           |
| recurrenceRule | String?       | RRule string (RFC 5545) for recurrence pattern |
| recurrenceEnd  | DateTime?     | End date for recurring tasks                   |
| createdAt      | DateTime      | Creation timestamp                             |
| updatedAt      | DateTime      | Last update timestamp                          |

content.title: PROJECTS: Create Model
content.body:
## Summary
Create the `Project` model.

A container for organizing related tasks.

## Fields
| Field       | Type          | Description                  |
| ----------- | ------------- | ---------------------------- |
| id          | String (cuid) | Unique identifier            |
| title       | String        | Project name                 |
| description | String?       | Optional project description |
| creatorId   | String        | User who owns the project    |
| startDate   | DateTime?     | Optional project start date  |
| endDate     | DateTime?     | Optional project end date    |
| createdAt   | DateTime      | Creation timestamp           |
| updatedAt   | DateTime      | Last update timestamp        |

## Notes
- No assignee.
- Align naming and constraints with existing schema conventions.

content.title: TASKS - Support labels, priority, and status on tasks
content.body:
Goal: Allow a task to have labels (can have more than one), priority, and status.

## Scope
- Update data model and database schema for task relationships.
- Expose API support to create, read, and update these task associations.

## Requirements
- A task can have multiple labels.
- A task can have one priority.
- A task can have one status.

content.title: DOCS: Harmonise models header
content.body: Harmonise the moldes file header

content.title: TASKS/PROJECTS: Add optional task-to-project association in data model
content.body:
## Goal
Allow a task to be associated to a project, while keeping this association optional.

## Requirements
- Update models so a task can reference one project.
- Keep project association optional (task may exist without project).
- Update Prisma schema and migration accordingly.
- Ensure relation integrity between `Task` and `Project` models.
- Update seed/data handling if needed to keep seed scripts consistent.

## Acceptance Criteria
- `Task` model supports nullable project reference.
- `Project` model exposes related tasks collection.
- Database migration applies cleanly.
- Existing task creation flow works when no project is provided.

## Notes
This issue is a blocker for API endpoints to assign/unassign tasks to projects.

content.title: API: Add endpoints to assign and unassign a task to/from a project
content.body:
## Goal
Adapt the API to manage task/project association.

## Requirements
- Add endpoint to assign a task to a project.
- Add endpoint to unassign a task from its project.
- Validate that task and project exist before assignment.
- Return consistent API responses and errors.
- Keep assignment optional (unassign sets project link to null).

## Acceptance Criteria
- API supports assigning a task to a project.
- API supports removing project association from a task.
- Invalid task/project IDs return expected error responses.
- Existing task endpoints remain backward compatible.

## Dependency
Blocked by #35.

content.title: PROJECTS: Add priority, status, and labels support to Project model
content.body:
## Goal
Bring Project metadata capabilities in line with Task by adding priority, status, and labels support.

## Problem
Task supports relations to priority, status, and labels, while Project currently does not.

## Scope
- Update Prisma Project model to support:
  - one optional priority
  - one optional status
  - many labels
- Update schema and migrations accordingly.
- Expose and propagate these fields through API and service layers where required.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Project can reference an optional Priority.
- Project can reference an optional Status.
- Project can reference multiple Label entries.
- Migration applies cleanly and existing project CRUD remains compatible.

content.title: Make tasks seed lookups case-insensitive for priority/status/labels/project
content.body:
## Summary
Align `server/prisma/seed/tasks.seed.ts` with `projects.seed.ts` by making relation lookups case-insensitive.

## Context
`projects.seed.ts` now normalizes lookup keys via lowercasing + trimming, so mixed-case seed references resolve correctly. `tasks.seed.ts` still uses case-sensitive maps for:
- `priorityName`
- `statusName`
- `labelNames`
- `projectTitle`

## Proposed changes
- Add a shared local helper (e.g. `toLookupKey(value: string)`) in `tasks.seed.ts`.
- Build lookup maps with normalized keys.
- Resolve incoming seed references using normalized keys.
- Keep existing fail/skip behavior unless explicitly changed.

## Acceptance criteria
- Mixed-case task seed values resolve correctly (e.g. `hIgH`, `in progress`, `baCkEnd`, `platform launch`).
- Existing canonical values continue to resolve as before.
- Seeding runs successfully without schema changes.

## Nice to have
- Optional follow-up: align error behavior in tasks seeding with projects seeding for missing references.

content.title: Standardize API JSON response envelope with pagination, sorting, and filter metadata
content.body:
## Summary
Standardize list endpoint responses so clients always receive a consistent JSON envelope that includes:
- total records
- paging information
- sorting information
- query/filter information

## Problem
Current API responses are not fully standardized across endpoints, which makes frontend integration and reusable data utilities harder. Consumers should not need endpoint-specific parsing logic for metadata.

## Proposal
Define and apply a common response structure for collection/list endpoints.

Example shape:
```json
{
  "data": [],
  "meta": {
    "total": 0,
    "paging": {
      "page": 1,
      "pageSize": 20,
      "totalPages": 0,
      "hasNext": false,
      "hasPrev": false
    },
    "sorting": {
      "sortBy": "createdAt",
      "order": "desc"
    },
    "filters": {
      "status": "todo",
      "priority": "high",
      "search": "auth"
    }
  }
}
```

## Scope
- Apply to all list endpoints (tasks, projects, users, labels, priorities, statuses, roles).
- Keep single-resource endpoints (`GET /:id`) unchanged unless explicitly needed.
- Ensure metadata reflects effective query values (including defaults).

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] A shared response contract is documented (README or docs).
- [ ] All list endpoints return the same top-level envelope (`data`, `meta`).
- [ ] `meta.total` returns total records matching applied filters (before page slicing).
- [ ] `meta.paging` includes page, pageSize, totalPages, hasNext, hasPrev.
- [ ] `meta.sorting` includes sort field and order.
- [ ] `meta.filters` echoes parsed query/filter params used by backend.
- [ ] Validation errors remain consistent with existing error middleware.
- [ ] Existing frontend consumers are updated or remain backward compatible.

## Notes
Consider introducing a reusable helper/utility in the server layer to avoid duplication and guarantee consistent structure across controllers/services.

content.title: Implement standardiseResponse across all API services
content.body:
## Summary
Standardize API service responses by implementing `standardiseResponse` consistently across all service modules.

## Objective
Ensure every API service method returns a unified response shape (success/error) using `standardiseResponse`, matching current project conventions.

## Scope
- Audit all files in `server/services/`.
- Apply `standardiseResponse` to endpoints/methods that are not yet standardized.
- Align HTTP status codes and message/error fields for consistency.
- Keep behavior backward-compatible where possible.

## Acceptance Criteria
- All service methods in `server/services/` return responses via `standardiseResponse`.
- Success responses include consistent `message`, `httpStatus`, and `data` when applicable.
- Error paths include consistent `message`, `httpStatus`, and `error`.
- No regressions in existing API behavior.

## Notes
Reference existing implementation patterns such as in `projects.service.ts` for consistency.

content.title: Create local SSO server for development using Keycloak container
content.body:
## Context
We need a local SSO server for development and integration testing.

Proposed solution: run **Keycloak** in a container and wire it to the local environment.

References:
- https://quay.io/repository/keycloak/keycloak
- https://www.keycloak.org/

## Goal
Provide a reproducible local SSO setup that developers can start with one command and use from the app/API during development.

## Scope
- Add a local Keycloak service (containerized) suitable for development.
- Define required environment variables and default ports.
- Configure a development realm/client/users (seed or documented manual steps).
- Document local startup, login flow, and token usage.
- Add integration notes for client/server configuration.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Developers can start Keycloak locally via container command(s).
- [ ] App and API can authenticate against local Keycloak in development mode.
- [ ] Required realm/client settings are documented or automated.
- [ ] Project documentation includes clear setup and troubleshooting steps.

## Notes
- Intended for **development purpose only** (not production hardening).
- Keep configuration simple and reproducible for onboarding.

content.title: Add comments model supporting tasks and projects
content.body:
## Context
We need a comments domain model where comments can be attached to both tasks and projects.

## Goal
Introduce a `Comment` model in the data layer and schema so the application can persist and query comments linked to tasks and projects.

## Scope
- Add Prisma `Comment` model and relations with `Task` and `Project`.
- Define required fields (id, content/body, author reference if applicable, timestamps).
- Define relation behavior and constraints (nullability, cascade behavior, indexes).
- Update migration(s) and generated client artifacts.
- Update schema documentation in `docs/`.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [x] `Comment` model exists in Prisma schema.
- [x] A task can have multiple comments.
- [x] A project can have multiple comments.
- [x] Migrations run successfully in local development.
- [x] Documentation reflects the new model and relations.

## Notes
- Keep naming and relation conventions aligned with existing models.

content.title: Implement comments API endpoints for tasks and projects
content.body:
## Context
After introducing the comments model, we need API endpoints to create and manage comments for tasks and projects.

## Goal
Expose REST endpoints to manage comments associated with tasks and projects in a consistent way with existing API patterns.

## Scope
- Add comments routes/controller/service modules.
- Implement create/read/update/delete endpoints for comments.
- Support listing comments by task and by project.
- Validate request payloads and return consistent error responses.
- Update route registration and API docs/README where relevant.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Endpoints exist to create/list/update/delete comments.
- [ ] Comments can be listed by task id.
- [ ] Comments can be listed by project id.
- [ ] Input validation and error handling follow existing conventions.
- [ ] Endpoint usage is documented for local development/testing.

## Notes
- Keep controller/service split aligned with existing modules (`tasks`, `projects`, etc.).

content.title: Refactor all remaining many-to-many relations to explicit join models with meaningful FK names
content.body:
## Context
We already applied explicit join models for comments to avoid implicit M:N join columns named `A` and `B`.

The same convention should be applied to all other many-to-many relations in the schema for consistency and readability.

## Goal
Replace remaining implicit many-to-many relations with explicit join models that use meaningful foreign key names (e.g. `taskId`, `labelId`, `projectId`, etc.).

## Scope
- Identify all remaining implicit M:N relations currently generating join tables with `A`/`B` columns.
- Create explicit join models for each relation.
- Use meaningful FK field names in join models.
- Keep or define clear table names via `@@map(...)` where needed.
- Update Prisma model relation fields in both related models.
- Generate and apply migration(s).
- Regenerate Prisma client/zod/docs.
- Update services/repositories if query shapes change.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] No remaining business-domain M:N relation relies on implicit `A`/`B` columns.
- [ ] Join tables expose meaningful FK column names.
- [ ] Migration applies successfully in local dev DB.
- [ ] `prisma generate` and server build pass.
- [ ] Documentation reflects updated relation models.

## Notes
- Maintain naming consistency with existing conventions introduced for comments.
- Avoid breaking API contracts unless explicitly planned and documented.

content.title: [Server] Add Swagger/OpenAPI documentation for API
content.body:
## Summary
Add Swagger/OpenAPI documentation to the server API so endpoints are discoverable, testable, and easier to maintain.

## Scope
- Integrate Swagger UI route in the Express server.
- Generate and expose OpenAPI spec for all current API routes.
- Document request/response schemas and status codes for core resources.
- Include setup/usage instructions in server docs.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Swagger UI is available from the running server.
- OpenAPI spec includes Users, Tasks, Projects, Labels, Statuses, Priorities, Roles, and Comments endpoints.
- Endpoint docs include payload examples and key response codes.
- README documents how to access and use Swagger locally.

## Notes
This issue is created as a **Feature** request.

projects.title: Github Project Helper
projects.shortDescription: Manage GitHub Project V2 statuses directly from VS Code with GitHub CLI integration

content.title: COMMAND: Updating GitHub Project Status
content.body:
Create a command to update the status of a GitHub project. The command should allow users to specify the project name, the new status, and any relevant details about the update. The command should also include error handling for cases where the project does not exist or the user does not have permission to update the project.

<!-- Edit the body of your new issue then click the ✓ "Create Issue" button in the top right of the editor. The first line will be the issue title. Assignees and Labels follow after a blank line. Leave an empty line before beginning the body of the issue. -->

content.title: Create an UI instead of commands

projects.title: Project Metrics Action
projects.shortDescription: A GitHub Action that automatically collects project statistics from GitHub Projects v2 and generates beautiful, badge-based metrics displays for organization profiles. It tracks task progress across all projects, analyzes programming language usage, and injects modular sections into README files wit

content.title: Remove link to the project if it is private
content.body:
The visitor should only have the link working if the project is public. Linking to a private project does not make sense or only if the visitor is part of the team.

A "lock" icon should be put after the project name for the private project.
A "earth" icon shold be put after the project name for the public project.

content.title: Add LICENSE file and link it in README
content.body:
## Summary
Add an open-source `LICENSE` file to the repository and reference it from `README.md`.

## Scope
- Add a `LICENSE` file at the repository root.
- Update `README.md` with a dedicated section or link pointing to the license.

## Acceptance Criteria
- `LICENSE` exists at the root and contains the chosen license text.
- `README.md` includes a visible link to `LICENSE`.
- Changes are committed in a PR and merged.

content.title: Add GitHub workflow to auto-update issue progress (like demo-task-manager)
content.body:
## Summary
Create a GitHub Actions workflow that updates issue progress automatically, following the same approach used in the `demo-task-manager` repository.

## Scope
- Identify the workflow pattern used in `demo-task-manager`.
- Implement equivalent workflow(s) in this repository.
- Configure required permissions and triggers.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Workflow file(s) are added under `.github/workflows/`.
- Issue progress updates are performed automatically on relevant events.
- Behavior is documented briefly in `README.md` (or repository docs).
- Changes are validated via a PR and merged.

content.title: Add repository list to README with visibility-aware linking
content.body:
## Context

Currently, the repositories attached to a project are only used to compute language usage statistics for the whole project. These repositories are already fetched and included in the JSON output (`data/projects.json`).

## Goal

List the repositories under each project in the generated README, but only show a clickable link for public repositories. Private repositories should still be listed (without a link).

## Requirements

1. **GraphQL query update** (`scripts/get_data.sh`):
   - Add `isPrivate` field to the repository query to expose visibility in JSON output

2. **README generation update** (`scripts/update_readme.sh`):
   - After language badges, list repositories under each project
   - For **public repositories**: show as clickable link `[owner/repo](url)`
   - For **private repositories**: show with lock icon (no link) `🔒 owner/repo`

## Example Output

```
### 🌐 Project Name
![Total](...) ![Done](...) ...

![TypeScript 40%](...) ![HTML 30%](...) ![CSS 30%](...)

**Repositories:**
- [MaquestiauxLabs/demo-angular-resume](https://github.com/MaquestiauxLabs/demo-angular-resume)
- 🔒 internal-backend
```

## Notes

- JSON output should keep all repositories (both public and private) to maintain language statistics functionality
- This follows the same pattern as project visibility handling in the current implementation
